title: Saudi Arabia’s capacity U-turn was months in the making
summary:
Reuters exclusively reported that Saudi Arabia’s surprise reversal of its oil expansion ambitions was at least six months in the […]
The post Saudi Arabia’s capacity U-turn was months in the making  appeared first on Reuters News Agency.
content:
Reuters exclusively reported that Saudi Arabia’s surprise reversal of its oil expansion ambitions was at least six months in the making, after Riyadh concluded its vast spare capacity was enough to supply markets during crises and further investments in new fields would make no economic sense. 
The post Saudi Arabia’s capacity U-turn was months in the making  appeared first on Reuters News Agency.

content:

title: Japan’s Inpex selling stake in Russian oil project to Itochu, sources say

The post Japan’s Inpex selling stake in Russian oil project to Itochu, sources say  appeared first on Reuters News Agency.
content:
Reuters exclusively reported that Inpex Corp (1605.T), Japan’s top oil and gas explorer, is selling its minority stake in a Russian oil project in Siberia to Japanese trading house Itochu Corp (8001.T). 
The post Japan’s Inpex selling stake in Russian oil project to Itochu, sources say  appeared first on Reuters News Agency.

title: Sony scrapped $10 bln India merger as Zee failed to meet financial terms
summary:
Reuters exclusively reported that Sony scrapped the $10 billion merger of its Indian arm with Zee Entertainment (ZEE.NS), in part […]
The post Sony scrapped $10 bln India merger as Zee failed to meet financial terms appeared first on Reuters News Agency.
content:
Reuters exclusively reported that Sony scrapped the $10 billion merger of its Indian arm with Zee Entertainment (ZEE.NS), in part because Zee failed to meet some financial terms of the deal and come up with a plan to address them.
The post Sony scrapped $10 bln India merger as Zee failed to meet financial terms appeared first on Reuters News Agency.

title: Russia struggles to sell Pacific oil, 14 tankers stuck
summary:
Reuters exclusively reported that more than a dozen tankers loaded with 10 million barrels of Russia’s Sokol grade crude oil […]
The post Russia struggles to sell Pacific oil, 14 tankers stuck appeared first on Reuters News Agency.
content:
Reuters exclusively reported that more than a dozen tankers loaded with 10 million barrels of Russia’s Sokol grade crude oil have been stranded off the coast of South Korea for weeks, so far unsold due to U.S. sanctions and payment issues, according to two traders and shipping data. 
The post Russia struggles to sell Pacific oil, 14 tankers stuck appeared first on Reuters News Agency.

title: Lloyds to cut around 1,600 branch jobs in digital switch
summary:
Reuters exclusively reported that Britain’s biggest domestic bank Lloyds was cutting around 1,600 roles across its branch network, part of […]
The post Lloyds to cut around 1,600 branch jobs in digital switch appeared first on Reuters News Agency.
content:
Reuters exclusively reported that Britain’s biggest domestic bank Lloyds was cutting around 1,600 roles across its branch network, part of a renewed push by lenders to axe costs as tough economic conditions and pressure on margins prompt them to tighten their belts. It is the latest in a string of deep cuts made by British banks – including Barclays, as also reported first by Reuters in November. The story was widely picked up, including by Bloomberg, the BBC and Sky News, as well as several newspapers including The Guardian, The Times, The Telegraph, The Daily Mail and The Daily Mirror.  
The post Lloyds to cut around 1,600 branch jobs in digital switch appeared first on Reuters News Agency.

title: China regulators ask funds to curb short selling of stock index futures
summary:
Reuters exclusively reported that China’s securities regulators have asked some hedge fund managers to restrict short selling in its stock […]
The post China regulators ask funds to curb short selling of stock index futures  appeared first on Reuters News Agency.
content:
Reuters exclusively reported that China’s securities regulators have asked some hedge fund managers to restrict short selling in its stock index futures market, as authorities seek to stabilise sinking stocks. 
The post China regulators ask funds to curb short selling of stock index futures  appeared first on Reuters News Agency.

summary:

The post Tesla plans to build new electric vehicles in mid-2025  appeared first on Reuters News Agency.
content:
Reuters exclusively reported that Tesla (TSLA.O), opens new tab has told suppliers it wants to start production of a new mass market electric vehicle codenamed “Redwood” in mid-2025. 
The post Tesla plans to build new electric vehicles in mid-2025  appeared first on Reuters News Agency.

title: Biden urges US Congress to approve F-16 sale to Turkey ‘without delay’
summary:
Reuters was first to report that Turkey’s parliament would debate Sweden’s NATO bid on Jan. 23, and then followed that […]
The post Biden urges US Congress to approve F-16 sale to Turkey ‘without delay’  appeared first on Reuters News Agency.
content:
Reuters was first to report that Turkey’s parliament would debate Sweden’s NATO bid on Jan. 23, and then followed that up with a series of exclusive news driving the rapid steps toward completion: U.S. President Joe Biden’s letter informing Congress that he intended to send members Turkey’s request to purchase F-16 fighter jets; an interview with the U.S. ambassador correcting predicting that President Erdogan would sign off on the legislation right away; and another scoop saying that the ratification would re-start Canada’s arms exports to Turkey after a bilateral deal was quietly reached between the sides.  
The post Biden urges US Congress to approve F-16 sale to Turkey ‘without delay’  appeared first on Reuters News Agency.

title: Thai central bank chief says current policy rate neutral, economy not in crisis
summary:
Reuters exclusively reported that Thailand’s central bank chief, under fire from the prime minister for not cutting rates, said slower-than-expected […]
The post Thai central bank chief says current policy rate neutral, economy not in crisis appeared first on Reuters News Agency.
content:
Reuters exclusively reported that Thailand’s central bank chief, under fire from the prime minister for not cutting rates, said slower-than-expected economic growth was not a crisis as portrayed by the government, nor would it be revived by its quick-hit stimulus measures. 
The post Thai central bank chief says current policy rate neutral, economy not in crisis appeared first on Reuters News Agency.

title: Wall Street Week: An Economy Better Than Goldilocks
summary: It’s hot where we want it to be, Paul Krugman says, but not where we don’t
content: A shopper inside a Uniqlo store in the Soho neighborhood of New York, US, on Monday, Jan. 22, 2024. US consumers rang in the new year with a good dose of optimism about the economy, their incomes and the inflation outlook, driving a gauge of confidence to a more than two-year high.

title: Skittish Investors Pull the Rug Out From Under Pricey US IPOs
summary: Wall Street has been talking up a much-needed revival of firms tapping markets for the first time after a two-year dearth of initial public offerings. But when it came to two of the three biggest debuts so far this year, investors didn’t want to hear it.

title: India’s SBI Misses Profit Estimate on Pension Provision
summary: State Bank of India’s profit for the latest quarter missed the average analyst estimate as the country’s biggest lender by assets kept aside more funds for pension liabilities.
content: A State Bank of India Ltd. (SBI) branch in Mumbai, India, on Thursday, Feb. 2, 2023. SBI has given loans of as much as $2.6 billion to companies in the Adani conglomerate, or about half of what is allowed under the rules, according to a person familiar with the matter.

title: Fire Extinguished at Russia’s Lukoil Plant After Drone Downed
summary: A fire at Lukoil PJSC’s refinery in Volgograd blamed on a downed drone was extinguished early Saturday following the latest attack by Ukraine on a Russian energy facility.
content: This photograph taken on March 17, 2022, shows Lukoil fuel storage tanks at Rosenets Port terminal near the city of Burgas at the Black sea coast. - Bulgaria cannot afford to back a ban on Russian oil and gas imports as part of sanctions against Moscow over its invasion of Ukraine, Prime Minister Kiril Petkov said on March 8. Sofia receives 77 percent of its natural gas from Russia's Gazprom and its sole oil refinery -- the largest on the Balkans -- is owned by Russia's Lukoil. (Photo by Nikolay DOYCHINOV / AFP) (Photo by NIKOLAY DOYCHINOV/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: NIKOLAY DOYCHINOV/AFP

title: ECB’s Elderson Sees ‘Good Progress’ on Bringing Inflation to 2%
summary: “As we’ve shown for almost the past two years and demonstrated again last week: we’re determined to bring inflation back down to our target of 2% and we’re making good progress,” European Central Bank Executive Board member Frank Elderson said in an interview with De Volkskrant.
content: Frank Elderson, executive board member of the European Central Bank, during a news conference in Frankfurt, Germany, on Tuesday, Dec. 19, 2023. The European Central Bank said capital requirements for the region’s lenders will rise to 11.1% next year from 10.7%, reflecting the impact of macroprudential policies. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

title: As Navies Focus on Red Sea Houthis, There Are Worrying Signs Somali Pirates Are Making a Comeback

content: Puntland Maritime Police Forces patrolling off the coast in Puntland, Somalia, Jan. 29.

title: Lynas Says It Held Talks With MP Materials on Potential Deal
summary: Lynas Rare Earths Ltd., one of the world’s largest producers of the raw materials, said it had been in confidential discussions with US-based MP Materials Corp. on a possible transaction but the talks are currently “not ongoing.”
content: The Lynas Rare Earths Ltd. processing plant in Kalgoorlie, Western Australia, on Wednesday, Aug. 3, 2022. Lynas, the only key supplier of the critical minerals outside China, has won further financial backing from Washington to build a plant in the US. Photographer: Carla Gottgens/Bloomberg

title: India Bets On Carbon Capture to Keep Its Coal Sector Viable
summary: India is set to launch a carbon capture policy that it says will allow it to keep exploiting its vast coal resources and deal with its growing emissions, according to to a top government energy adviser.
content: The central chimneys at the coal-fired NTPC Ltd. Dadri Power Plant in Gautam Budh Nagar district, Uttar Pradesh, India, on Thursday, Oct. 7, 2021. India, which relies on coal for about 70% of electricity generation, has already seen signs of power shortages, and needs to lift deliveries to avert the risk of blackouts.

title: Balance of Power 02/02/24
summary: "Balance of Power" focuses on the intersection of politics and global business. On the show today, Heather Boushey, member of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, discusses the strong January jobs report that showed the United States created 353,000 jobs, saw the unemployment rate at 3.7%, and wages increase. James Jeffrey, Former US Ambassador to Iraq and Turkey, discusses the United States striking Iran-backed militias in Syria and Iraq in retaliation to a drone attack that killed three US troops. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: China’s Lunar New Year Pork Gloom Exposes Deep Economic Trouble
summary: For families across China preparing for Lunar New Year, the most important celebration in the calendar, pork is a must. An ingredient synonymous with prosperity and abundance, it’s used in countless dishes and cured for festive delicacies.
content: Pork for sale at a wholesale market in Beijing.

title: Wall Street Week 02/02/2024
summary: On this edition of Wall Street Week, Peter Kraus, Aperture Investors Founder and CEO and Sonal Desai, Franklin Templeton Fixed Income CIO weigh the Fed's plans to cur rates following a blowout January jobs report. Chris Miller, Chip War author describes the global push by governments to invest in advanced chips. Paul Krugman, Nobel Laureate in Economics and Distinguished Professor at City University of NY Graduate Center tells us what kind of president the economy needs  over the next four years and Lawrence H. Summers, Former US Treasury Secretary tells us why a March rate cut is off the table. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Wall Street Week Votes: What the Economy Needs in the Next Four Years
summary: Paul Krugman, Nobel Laureate in Economics and Distinguished Professor at City University of NY Graduate Center tells us the US needs a president that will be thinking about the long-term and dives into Trump and Biden's dueling economic policies. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Chip Competition
summary: Chris Miller, Chip War author explains the AI boom and how it's impacting the chip industry. He tells us why governments around the world are investing in their own chip industries in order to remain competitive. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Summers: Surprised, not Shocked by January Jobs Numbers
summary: Lawrence H. Summers, Former US Treasury Secretary and Wall Street Week contributor, takes us through the January jobs report and explains why he believes the Fed did the right thing by taking March cuts off the table. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Bloomberg Markets: The Close 02/02/2024
summary: Bloomberg Television brings you the latest news and analysis leading up to the final minutes and seconds before and after the closing bell on Wall Street. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Yield in Private Equity
summary: Peter Kraus, Aperture Investors Founder and CEO and Sonal Desai, Franklin Templeton Fixed Income CIO debate whether we have seen the peak in private markets. Desai also shares that liquid markets appear to be optimistic about fixed income. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Not at that Glitters is Gold
summary: We take a look at successes that seemed too good to be true from Bernie Madoff to Enron. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Consequences of Elections
summary: We take a look back at the consequences from presidential elections from market reactions to US employment and what challenges the future president will face. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: China Gloom Spurs Record $2 Billion Rush Into Foreign Stock ETFs
summary: A record amount of Chinese money is flowing into overseas equities as despondent investors seek a way out of the sagging local stock market.

title: Fed’s Goolsbee Says He Wants to See More Inflation Progress
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago President Austan Goolsbee said he wants to see more evidence the Fed is on track toward its 2% inflation goal before cutting interest rates, though he stopped short of ruling out a reduction in March.
content: Chicago Fed President Austan Goolsbee

title: Stock Bull Run Powers Ahead as US Economy Roars: Markets Wrap
summary: The stock market extended this week’s gains as big tech rallied and a solid jobs report bolstered the outlook for corporate profits.
content: Investors didn't differentiate among regional lenders in the wake of New York Community Bancorp's earnings disappointment, selling off stocks across the industry on concern over commercial real estate exposure, according to Bloomberg's Sally Bakewell and Herman Chan of Bloomberg Intelligence.

title: Energy's Impact on US-Iran Relations
summary: Iran and the US have a long and tangled political history, yet one clear thread between them is the energy sector. Tyler Kendall has more on the relationship between the two countries, as the US strikes in retaliation for an Iranian-backed attack.  (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Kredit Academy Founder on Managing Credit
summary: Kredit Academy is a software platform that helps people manage their debt. Founder Evan Leaphart discusses how it works, who he's patterning with, and describes the difference between good debt and bad debt. He speaks with Scarlet Fu and Romaine Bostick on "Bloomberg Markets: The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Apollo Affiliate Refinances NYC Luxury Tower Owned by RXR, GO
summary: An Apollo Global Management Inc. affiliate refinanced a New York apartment tower.
content: Buildings in the Manhattan skyline in New York, U.S., on Thursday June 17, 2021. New York state's pandemic mandates were lifted last week, after 70% of the adult population has now been given at least one dose of a coronavirus vaccine. Photographer: Victor J. Blue/Bloomberg
